did.unittitle: Logic of Computers Group (University of Michigan) Records 1950-1979
did.abstract: Interdepartmental University of Michigan faculty group formed in 1956 and headed by Arthur Burks to investigate the use of computers in communication. Records include correspondence, project reports, grant proposals and some personal papers of Arthur Burks.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

did.physloc: Portions located in offsite storage; prior notification required for access.

acqinfo.p: The records were donated by Arthur M. Burks in October 1984 and 1986. Donor No. 7118

accessrestrict.p: The record group is open without restriction.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Logic of Computers Group (University of Michigan) Records, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: The Logic of Computers Group (LoCG) at the University of Michigan was established in 1956 as an informal group of faculty members from various departments who were interested in studying the logical formalisms related to computers and natural systems. The group was directed by philosophy professor Arthur Burks and early an worked out Of the Operations Research Department of the Engineering Research Institute. In 1957, Burks and Gordon Peterson, of the Phonetics Laboratory in the Department of Speech, petitioned the graduate school, and along with five other professors were constituted a committee with power to award advanced graduate degrees in "Communications Sciences." The program was chaired by Peterson until it achieved departmental status in 1965. After a year under an interim chairman, Burks chaired the "Computer and Communications Sciences" Department until 1971. The LoCG was an important component of both the early program and, later, the department. Although it worked out of its own computing center and was funded entirely by grants from governmental agencies, it provided the department with faculty expertise and produced a large percentage of the departmental PhDs.

scopecontent.p: The Logic of Computers Group records (12 linear feet)document some of the earliest use of and research on computing on the University of Michigan campus. The records are divided into six series: CONCOMP; Correspondence; Grants and Proposals; Papers and Reports; Arthur Burks Personal files; and Photographs.

controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan. Logic of Computers Group.
controlaccess.subject: Computers.

scopecontent.p: The University of Michigan CONCOMP project involved research in the conversational use of Computers and was supported by the Department of Defense. The files here (one linear foot) consist almost entirely of published "Technical Reports" and, "Memoranda" that resulted from the research. The reports are arranged alphabetically by the last name of the author. It is uncertain how many of the authors were members of the LoCG.
The correspondence files (one linear foot) are from the years 1961-1963 and 1968-1979. They are arranged chronologically and consist of outgoing correspondence by members of the LoCG.

The Grants and Proposals files (two and one half linear feet) contain correspondence, memos, and proposal drafts. They are arranged alphabetically by agency to which the proposals were directed and grants received from. Within agency, the files are arranged alphabetically by last name of the University of Michigan project leader or proposal originator (the majority of whom are Burks) and thereafter, alphabetically by project title.

scopecontent.p: The Papers and Reports files 5.5 linear feet) are arranged alphabetically by the last name of the author. They are primarily those that were generated by members of the LoCG as a result of grants received from and projects funded by the federal government. Together with the Grants and Proposals files, they document the areas of research in which the group concentrated, and the results achieved.

The Arthur Burks Personal files are arranged alphabetically by topic. Included are materials related to his work in the early 1950s as University of Michigan project leader for research done on the application of electronic computers to accounting problems. The research was contracted by the Burroughs Corporation. There are also materials from his service (both as member and as chairman) on the University Computer, Policy Committee, which was concerned with the requirements and utilization of university computer resources. There are interesting articles by Burks on the development of ENIAC, (the first electronic, digital, general-purpose scientific computer) with which he was associated, and there is a file containing background materials on the LoCG which provide an introduction to the history of the group.

scopecontent.p: The Photographs subgroup consists of five photos of an IBM 1800 computer being moved into the LoCG computer room
